<html><head><title>FTP Tutorial - Part 1</title>
<!--Description and keywords generated by script--><meta name="description" content="Learn how to use FTP to upload files to your site so that everyone in the world can see them. (Free Webmaster Help)">
<meta name="keywords" content="ftp, file, transfer, protocol, how, to, upload, download, explain, tutorial, help">
<!-- Standard Heading -->
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<script language="JavaScript">
<!--
function MM_swapImgRestore() { //v3.0
  var i,x,a=document.MM_sr; for(i=0;a&&i<a.length&&(x=a[i])&&x.oSrc;i++) x.src=x.oSrc;
}

function MM_preloadImages() { //v3.0
  var d=document; if(d.images){ if(!d.MM_p) d.MM_p=new Array();
    var i,j=d.MM_p.length,a=MM_preloadImages.arguments; for(i=0; i<a.length; i++)
    if (a[i].indexOf("#")!=0){ d.MM_p[j]=new Image; d.MM_p[j++].src=a[i];}}
}

function MM_findObj(n, d) { //v4.0
  var p,i,x;  if(!d) d=document; if((p=n.indexOf("?"))>0&&parent.frames.length) {
    d=parent.frames[n.substring(p+1)].document; n=n.substring(0,p);}
  if(!(x=d[n])&&d.all) x=d.all[n]; for (i=0;!x&&i<d.forms.length;i++) x=d.forms[i][n];
  for(i=0;!x&&d.layers&&i<d.layers.length;i++) x=MM_findObj(n,d.layers[i].document);
  if(!x && document.getElementById) x=document.getElementById(n); return x;
}

function MM_swapImage() { //v3.0
  var i,j=0,x,a=MM_swapImage.arguments; document.MM_sr=new Array; for(i=0;i<(a.length-2);i+=3)
   if ((x=MM_findObj(a[i]))!=null){document.MM_sr[j++]=x; if(!x.oSrc) x.oSrc=x.src; x.src=a[i+2];}
}
//-->
</script>

            			<!-- Page Title -->
                       <p align="center"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="5"><b><font color="#000099" size="6">
                       FTP Tutorial<br>
              <font size="4" color="#000000">Part 1 - Introduction to FTP</font></font></b></font></p>

              <!-- Links To Other Tutorial Parts -->
              <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><ul><li><b>Part 1 - Introduction to FTP</b></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/ftp/2">Part 2 - Transferring Files</a></li></ul></font>

              <!-- Page Content -->
              <p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">
              <div align="right" style="float:right">
<iframe src="http://rcm.amazon.com/e/cm?t=freewebmaster-20&o=1&p=14&l=st1&mode=books&search=ftp&fc1=000000&lt1=&lc1=3366FF&bg1=FFFFFF&f=ifr" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" width="160" height="600" border="0" frameborder="0" style="border:none;" scrolling="no"></iframe>
</div><font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Introduction</b></big></font><br />
<br />
FTP is an essential part of the internet, not only for people building web sites but also for people downloading files. FTP stands for File Transfer Protocol and is the best way of sending files from one computer to another over the internet.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Software</b></big></font><br />
<br />
Depending on what you are planning to do with your FTP software you should pick different ones. There are hundreds of free pieces of software so there is a very good choice. The three software packages I will cover in this tutorial are:<br />
<ul><li>Cute FTP</li><li>FTP Explorer</li><li>Elite FTP</li></ul><br />
Each of these has its own good and bad points.<br />
<br />
Cute FTP used to be the best shareware FTP program around. It is easy to use and has many functions. Unfortunately, because it has become so popular, the latest version only allows you to transfer one file at a time unless you register. If you can find a copy of version 2.6.* it is an excellent program. You can find Cute FTP here.<br />
<br />
FTP Explorer is not such a good program as Cute FTP but it is freeware so there are no annoying nag-screens. It can be downloaded here.<br />
<br />
Elite FTP is not such a good program for uploading standard files but I think it works better if you are working with CGI as you can send commands to the server by typing them in. I would only suggest this for CGI as it does not work with some servers properly and for some reason can&#039;t rename files! You can download it here.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Downloading Files</b></big></font><br />
<br />
One good reason to use FTP is to download files. FTP is much faster than standard HTTP downloads (through your browser). The two ways to download via FTP are quite easy. One is to find the file you want on the internet and then copy the shortcut to the file. After doing this open your FTP program and paste it into the Quick Connect dialog box. Click OK and the program will connect to the file and begin to download it.<br />
<br />
The second way to download a file via FTP is to connect to a download site through the software and then navigate through it to find the files you want. Follow the instructions below to connect. Usually these sites allow you to log in using anonymous FTP. This means that you either do not enter a user name and password or use anonymous as your user name and your e- mail address as your password. Two servers you can use to download files are ftp.download.com and ftp.cdrom.com.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Connecting To A Server</b></big></font><br />
<br />
Because there are so many FTP programs you could use I will show you how to use FTP Explorer. Most of them look the same, though, and this technique will work with most of them.<br />
<br />
When you open the FTP program a connection dialog box will appear (if it doesn&#039;t you should run the Site Manager or something similar). It will look like <a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/static/tutorials/ftp/connect.gif">this</a>.<br />
<br />
This is the screen where you need to enter all the information for a connection you want to set up. This will be saved so you only need to enter it once. The following may appear on this screen. Some of the names may be different and all of them may not appear.<br />
<br />
<table border="1" cellspacing="2" cellpadding="2" align="center"><tr> <td><font color="#000099"><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Setting</font></b></font></td><td><font color="#000099"><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Description</font></b></font></td></tr><tr> <td><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Profile Name</font></b></td><td><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">A name for the profile you have just created on your computer. This is just a name for you to remember the connection by.<<br />
/font></td></tr><tr> <td><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Host Address</font></b></td><td><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">This is the server the computer will connect to (like ftp.download.com). It will be given to you by your web host or download site.</font></td></tr><tr> <td><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Port</font></b></td><td><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">This is the port on the remote computer the software will connect to. It does not normally need to be changed.</font></td></tr><tr> <td><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Login</font></b></td><td><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Your user name. If you do not have one put in anonymous (and select the anonymous or anonymous login option)</font></td></tr><tr> <td><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Password</font></b></td><td><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Your password. For anonymous login either use your e-mail address or leave blank.</font></td></tr><tr> <td><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Initial Path</font></b></td><td><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">The first directory which will be opened on the remote computer. This is normally not used.</font></td></tr><tr> <td><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Attempts</font></b></td><td><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">This is the number of times the computer will try to download (or upload) a file if it is interrupted.</font></td></tr><tr> <td><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Retry Delay</font></b></td><td><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">The time between each retry.</font></td></tr><tr> <td><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Download Path</font></b></td><td><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">The directory on your computer where files will be downloaded to.</font></td></tr><tr> <td><b><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">Description</font></b></td><td><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif">An area where you can put notes for yourself which will be stored with the connection information.</font></td></tr></table><br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>What Now?</b></big></font><br />
<br />
Now you are connected to an FTP site. If you want to you can now go on and download or upload files (it is quite easy to get the hang of). If you aren&#039;t sure what to do then read on. In the next part we will cover how to transfer files to and from your computer.</font></p>

              <!-- Bottom Navigation -->
              <table width="100%" cellspacing="2" cellpadding="2" border="0">
              <tr>
              
              
              
              <!-- Links To Other Tutorial Parts -->
              <td width="50%" valign="top"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><ul><li><b>Part 1 - Introduction to FTP</b></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/ftp/2">Part 2 - Transferring Files</a></li></ul></font></p></td>
              
              <!-- Related Links -->
              <td width="50%" valign="top">
              <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><ul>
                   <li><a href="http://www.cuteftp.com">Cute FTP</a></li><li><a href="http://www.ftpx.com">FTP Explorer</a></li><li><a href="http://www.seagullsw.com">BlueZone FTP</a></li><li><a href="http://www.free-webhosting.info">Free-Webhosting.info</a></li><li><a href="http://www.meteorsurf.com/cgi-bin/smartsearch/smartsearch.cgi?username=gowansnet&keywords=ftp">More FTP Sites</a></li><li><a href="#amazonlinks">Related Reading</a></li>
</ul></font>
</td>

			 <!-- End Bottom Navigation -->
			 </tr></table>

        	<!-- Gowansnet Link -->
            
            
             </td><td width="9">&nbsp;</td>
        </tr>
      </table>
    </td>
  </tr>
